contextId.information: Here "glory" represents the presence of Yahweh. AT: "so that he may show you the glory of his presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: so that his glory may appear to you

contextId.information: Here "glory" represents Yahweh's presence. AT: "Yahweh showed all the people the glory of his presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the glory of Yahweh appeared to all the people

contextId.information: Here "assembly" means the whole congregation of Israel, not just a group of leaders. AT: "not be angry with all the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: not be angry with all the assembly

contextId.information: This refers to the people groups already living in Canaan. Translate this so the term "nations" is clarified as people. AT: "the people of the nations defiled themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the nations are defiled

contextId.information: Here the words "nation" and "land" represent the people who live there. Many people practicing prostitution and other wicked deeds is spoken of as if the they have fallen into or become full of those things. AT: "the people will begin to practice prostitution and many wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the nation will fall to prostitution and the land will become full of wickedness

contextId.information: God's name represents God and his reputation. AT: "dishonor my reputation" or "dishonor me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: profane my holy name

contextId.information: The phrase "to close their eyes" implies they "cannot see" and  represents their inability to understand. AT: "disregard" or "ignore" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: close their eyes to

contextId.information: This word "name" is used to represent Yahweh's character. AT: "not disgrace God's reputation" or "not disgrace their God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: not disgrace the name of their God

contextId.information: Here "bread" represents food in general. Yahweh does not actually eat these offerings. Translate this in a way that makes it clear that Yahweh does not actually eat the food. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for he is the one who offers bread to your God

contextId.information: The word "profane" here means to dishonor. The word "name" represents Yahweh's character. AT: "dishonor my reputation" or "dishonor me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: profane my holy name

contextId.information: The requirement that people assemble to worship God on that day is spoken of as if that day were the assembly. AT: "a holy day, when you must assemble together to worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a holy assembly

contextId.information: The requirement that people assemble on that day is spoken of as if that day were the assembly. Being set apart to Yahweh means that when they assemble, they must worship Yahweh. AT: "The seventh day is a day when you must assemble together to worship Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The seventh day is an assembly set apart to Yahweh

contextId.information: The phrase "covenant decrees" represents either the tablets that the decrees were written on or the box that the tablets were put in. These were kept in the very holy place, which was the room behind the curtain in the tent of meeting. AT: "Outside the curtain that is in front of the tablets of the covenant decrees" or "Outside the curtain that is in front of the box of the covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Outside the curtain before the covenant decrees

contextId.information: Here the word "sword" represents enemy armies or enemy attacks. AT: "no armies will attack you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the sword will not pass through your land

contextId.information: Here the word "sword" represents an army or an attack from an army. AT: "I will bring an enemy army against you" or "I will cause an enemy army to attack you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will bring a sword on you

contextId.information: Here "into the hand" means "into the control" and refers to defeat by their enemy. This can be stated in active form. AT: "your enemy will defeat you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: you will be delivered into the hand of your enemy

contextId.information: Listening represents obeying what he has said. AT: "If you do not obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If you do not listen to me

contextId.information: Because God would send an army to do these things, he speaks as if he would do them. AT: "I will send an enemy army to destroy ... cut down ... throw your corpses"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will destroy ... cut down ... throw your corpses

contextId.information: Because God would send armies to do these things, he speaks as if he would do them. AT: "I will send enemy armies to turn your cities into ruins and destroy your sanctuaries" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I will turn your cities into ruins and destroy your sanctuaries

contextId.information: The sword represents either someone who is ready to kill using a sword or an attack from an enemy army. AT: "as though you were fleeing from someone who was chasing you with a sword" or "as though you were fleeing from an enemy army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: as though you were fleeing from the sword

contextId.information: The sword represents either someone who is ready to kill using a sword or an attack from an enemy army. AT: "as though you were running away from someone who was chasing you with a sword" or "as though you were running away from an enemy army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: as though you were running from the sword

contextId.information: Here "their fathers" represents their ancestors. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: their fathers' sins

contextId.information: This represents the people of the nations. AT: "in the sight of the people of the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the nations

contextId.information: Here "a homer of barley" represents a piece of land that would need one homer of barley in order to plant on all of it. AT: "a piece of land that requires one homer of barley in order to plant all of it will be valued at" or 'the value of land that requires one homer of barley will be" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: a homer of barley will be valued at

contextId.information: This refers to the the way they would count their animals.  AT: "when you count your animals by raising your shepherd rod and having them walk under it to the other side" or "when you count the animals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: whatever passes under the shepherd's rod
